childnodes.sy: This Basque-American drink really packs a punch. With Amer Picon almost impossible to find in the states, this recipe is as close to the original as we can get.
This tea-like Peruvian drink has been sold on the streets of Lima for over a hundred years and is renowned for is't refreshing taste and medicinal properties.
Though not as trendy as Kombucha, this traditional Russian fermented beverage has been served throughout Eastern Europe since the Middle ages.
This 500 year old Arabic Coffee is a complex caffeinated combination of flavors.
Most Americans don't know Milo, but pretty much every other kid around the globe loves it. It's a delicious drink, not to mention has a lot of potential for ... experimentation.
For the season finale and the winner of the viewer's choice, we're making Tibetan Butter Tea! Acquired taste? Yes. Worth trying? Absolutely.
In the Northwest, it can get pretty foggy and cold. So if you're looking for a good defense, make yourself some London Fog.
Often drank by farmers during harvest, Switchel is pretty much an old school energy drink. So why not dip back into a bit of American history, and give this full flavored drink a try.
This drink is beloved throughout much of the Middle East, especially during Ramadan. If you don't like apricot, this isn't going to work out. But any apricot-phile is going to dig this.
When it's the time of year where you need a delicious, warming drink in your arsenal ... trust us, this is it.
When you're drifting along, with the tumbling tumbleweeds, you might set your eyes on a prickly pear, and not know what to do with it. Well, the answer is, this.

You might not lust after Doogh like you would a Sweet Tea or a Bandung - but trust us, one sip of this while eating a chelo-kebab, and you'll understand why this drink has been in rotation in the Middle East since ancient times.
A cousin to Falooda, Alouda is inescapable as you walk down the streets of Port Louis. It's refreshing, delicious, and filling.
People have been drinking Aloe Vera for thousands of years - why? It's super healthy for you, and makes a great base for a whole bevvy of beverages.
From Kit Kat's to Starbucks, Matcha is popping up everywhere these days. This week, we present the traditional method for making this amazingly creamy, full bodied tea.
This drink takes a long, long time to make - worth it? Absolutely. Delicate, sweet, and gratifying, you won't make Sikhye everyday - but it's a drink you should try to make at least once.
Sorrel is favorite in the Caribbean (and many other parts of the world, where they call it Hibiscus Tea, Agua de Jamaica ... the list goes on).
If you like Horchata but are looking for something a bit heartier (thanks to the rolled oats), then this is the drink for you.
When life gives you lemons - make Mazagran. Seriously, the Portuguese know their coffee, so trust them on this one.
This smoothie is not only delicious, but packed with nutrients that keep you energized throughout the day - it's a double win.
Some describe this drink from the Dominican Republic as an orange creamsicle in liquid form - we just describe it as awesome.
Bubble Tea (aka Boba), needs no introduction. You've had it many times - though the thought of making it at home seems daunting. It's not. And it tastes delicious.
Though not a drink of antiquity, The Greeks have been sipping on this refreshing boost of caffeine for years ... and for good reason, it's delicious!
Though this drink was originally created for Pehlwani wrestlers to get refreshed and energized before a fight - you don't have to get in to a ring to enjoy the intriguing taste of this drink.
It's Summer. You should be in Hawaii. We should all be in Hawaii. Though if you can't get there, why not make this stellar drink from the Aloha State.

Get patriotic this 4th of July, with this fun, non-alcoholic smoothie. There are a few steps involved, but a dip in the pool, and a bit of grilling later, and you've got yourself a fun, colorful Holiday drink!

This drink would fit right in at any new, hip juicing bar ... though it was actually developed by a Japanese doctor in the 1940's, who knew then what people know now: these ingredients are a nutrient powerhouse.
Even in the dead of Summer, people are drinking this sweet, full bodied tea. And though the ingredients are simple, the technique takes some practice - thankfully the end result is worth it.
Rhubarb is so hot right now ... so if you wanna be cool (and cool off) why not try this refreshing Polish drink.
Even though this Agua Fresca is dead simple to make, it's pretty much the most refreshing thing you could ever make with watermelon.
Step out onto a street in Chile in the Summertime, and you're likely to find this fruity and filling drink - trust us, it's pretty darn peachy.
Peanuts, milk, sugar ... what's not to like? This refreshing drink from Trinidad (and all over the Caribbean) is easy to make, and tastes great. And yes, adding bitters is essential.
Created in Spain, many countries have their own version of Horchata. This recipe is inspired by the regional rice-based variations across Mexico.
Yerba Mate is a type of tea, but it goes way beyond being just a tea. Earthy, pungent, and steeped in ritual, it's something you must try.
Whether it's for its beautiful color, its health benefits, or because you just want to be refreshed, this sweet Summertime beverage is something you have to try.
Whether for breakfast, lunch, or any time really, this refreshing Indian drink, is sure to cool you off and fill your tummy.
This traditional Korean drink, balances the delicate pear flavor with a strong hit of ginger - all combining to create a wonderful drink for someone who's a bit under the weather.
A perfect Summer drink that's also super healthy for you (thanks to the Chia seeds).
This is a rich, sweet, caffeinated treat, that's anything but your average cup of coffee.
Sweet, creamy deliciousness - pair this tea with a spicy dish and you're in for a treat.
With a rich cultural history and complex taste, Masala Chai is one of the most delicious teas in existence. Enjoy!
Celebrate Chinese New Year in style, with this traditional Beijing sweet drink.
Take a trip to Southeast Asia, with this sweet, spicy, traditional Indonesian drink.
A classic Swedish drink recipe, handmade from the Blueberry's Nordic cousin, the Bilberry! No trip to IKEA required.
Coffee drinkers of the world, get ready for a very strange brew. A delicious, little known method of making coffee that requires, you guessed it, an egg.
A delicious hot Mexican fruit punch that is perfect on a cold night. Filled with sweet and tangy fruit flavors, this is one of our new favorite winter drinks.
Break out your Christmas sweaters, it's Eggnog time! Whether you love it or hate it, Eggnog is a full on holiday tradition, and nothing tastes better than homemade.
Hey baby, it's cold outside. Warm yourself up with this delicious homemade apple cider recipe, courtesy of the Tastemade original series.
A thick, warm, chocolate-based drink from Mexico that's unlike any hot chocolate you've ever tasted. Grab your molinillos, it's champurrado time!
